Description: Body sherd of thick-walled Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery dinos; creamy slip; exterior, from top: black-figure sphinxes to left (of that on left head, forelegs, and part of wing missing; added red on wing; of right sphinx, chin, neck, chest and foreleg remaining; red on wing); incised pendant rosettes and triangle as filling ornament; wide black band; lower frieze of lions to right, snout of lion on left, part of tail of second on right; incised rosette and incised pendant rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lamb identifies the sherd as coming from a pyxis and Lemos suggests it comes from a stemmed bowl. However, the lack of a slip on the interior (a slip would be expected on pyxides, bowls and skyphos kraters) points more closely to Chian dinoi which are typically unslipped on their interior. For parallels with other dinoi, see British Museum 1888,0601.459. For parallels regarding the decorative scheme, see Oxford AN1896-1908-G.120.17. Lemos places this sherd in Group C of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The vases in this group may all have been decorated by the same painter. The cogwheel rosettes have more spikes and the figures are well executed.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 148, p. 311, no. 1300, pl. 168)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 34, no. 60, pl. XVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0039) (phase 2)
